Whether we like it or not humans are deluded animals, just like all other animals.

The only difference from other animals is that humans tend to have a higher percentage of consciously-logical thinking. And I said "tend" because there are humans with mental retardation and other mental problems who have a lower percentage of consciously logical thinking than healthy apes.

When I mention percentage of consciously-logical thinking I mean humans are both partially consciously-rational and partially unconsciously-rational animals.
Instincts, emotions, and other unconcious processes are what motivates humans to stay alive, work, dance, do art, and other things that may increase chances of reproduction that keep those genes in nature.

For intelligent machines to ever get a will of their own they would need to be given needs, emotions, and other motivations to act. Logic itself is not a motivation.

Only those genes which produce individuals who behave in a way that leads to their reproduction are the ones to continue active in nature.

All animals are 100% rational, but while humans may be 40% to 70% consciously rational, the other animals have a lower percentage of conscious rationality.

Because instincts take a long time to change in response to environmental changes, some animals eventually evolved conscious rationality which helped them survive relatively faster changes in food supply, weather, predators, terrain, etc.

Because of the unconscious nobody has free will.

Nick:

If we discard supernatural explanations, everything about humans is a product of evolutionary pressures on our animal and early human ancestors. Our ethical sense, too, had to originate in our evolutionary past - because it could not arise anywhere else! If we do not yet understand how it arose, that's merely because we have not yet found the explanation. Perhaps we never will. Perhaps we are not smart enough as a species to understand everything about ourselves. Why should that surprise anyone?

Some ethologists are now, finally, designing experiments to explore the moral sense (or parallels thereto) in other species. It's about time.

Call it political expediency or a sign of prudent pragmatism of a former professor of constitutional law, Obama's reluctance to indulge in the politics of judicial activism of nominating judges of personal choice or preferred ideological persuasion, did, in fact, reveal a great sense of understanding and appreciation on his part for the compulsions of constitutional governance, based on checks and balances. His deliberate posture of maintaining ideological equidistance between the two extremes of liberal and conservative orthodoxies while making judicial nominations did not only spare him of unsavoury controversies, but also allowed him time to concentrate on his socially oriented legislative agenda, like the Affordable Healthcare Act, job and infrastructure related bills or the economic stimulus. While it was not all a success at that; still, given the stubborn stance of the Republican obstructionism, and the Senate's filibustering, what Obama did was not a mean achievemnent, specially when it all involved a thin edge walking for him. So, in the absence of requisite constitutional amendments, specially the Senate power reforms, any  move to indulge in judicial nominations overdrive on the part of Obama would have proved counterproductive. This cautious approach adopted by Obama on judicial nominations did really bear fruit, when his signature legislation on the healthcare reforms was upheld by the sharply divided Supreme Court.

Or, consider my Aunt Mary, once a brilliant pioneering attorney in a time when few women were able to make their way into the legal profession.  At 80 or so, her mind tragically began to slip. She started writing checks to every scam that came her way posing as a charity, sometimes writing checks to them over and over again because this once highly organized woman  now couldn't keep track of what checks she had already written, and certainly couldn't remember. Yet her doctor and her lawyer both told me she wasn't incompetent enough to declare incompetent, and so I had to stand by and just hope that she wouldn't spend all the money that might be needed to take care of her some day.  Now, imagine her, with Mr. Ryan's voucher in hand, trying to navigate the private health insurance market.

My mother needed our help to get the Medicare stuff lined up.  The thought of her shopping around for an insurer with a coupon, or a voucher in her  hand is unfathomable.  She would either get ripped off or go uninsured.  This will happen to many seniors if the Ryan plan were to take effect.  My mother took care of us when we were small and we took care of her when she got older.  What will happen to seniors who for whatever reason are on their own or only have other seniors for companions.  The Ryan Medicare plan is okay for wealthy seniors.  For the rest, it is just plain cruel.

quoting JGM: "2...Only a handful of states allow an adult adoptee unrestricted access to the original document. And even then, the falsified birth certificate is still the adoptee's only legally-recognized birth record--in every state, even those that allow an adoptee to obtain a copy of the original. Not one exception."

To clarify for readers what this means: "unrestrictive access" does not mean the adoptee is issued a certified, operable, legal original birth certificate. In the few states that passed these laws, adoptees are given photocopies with any of these words stamped across the front: "Not for Official Use" or "Void" or "For Genealogical Purposes Only" or "Not a Legal Document".

Be very clear about this. NO adoptee is equal to any non-adoptee, ever. We will not become equal until we are given full certified legal copies of our true birth certificates certifying our births. The government must officially reinstate the validity of the truth of our births.

Our false birth certificates must be declared null and void. Replace our legal and false birth certificates with Adoption Certificates stating the facts of adoption certified with the signature of the Registrar of Vital Statistics and State Seal.

Both documents are to be used as Identification and citizenship. This is the way it is done in more progressive countries, such as Holland. I have been trying to obtain English translation of the Dutch law to introduce Federal Legislation here in USA.

In response to half orphan:

South Korea has most definitely not stopped adoptions. Their goal is to stop international adoptions within a few years, and to have children adopted domestically instead.

Few children are available for adoption in the Netherlands -- but the government has not outlawed adoption, as you imply. There is a huge interest there in international adoption, but the process is slow and difficult there as it is everywhere. Again, this is not because it was outlawed by the Netherlands.

You cannot legislate away adoption. There will always be cases where children need homes.

The one thing you said that makes sense to me is that adoptees should be issued an adoption certificate, which they can use as documentation if they so choose, but I do not agree that it should replace the updated "birth" certificate that is issued once the adoption is finalized.

I am not sure how having a "falsified" (or updated) birth certificate makes one unequal. The 14th amendment applies to adoptees as well as non adoptees.

I was rejected by my mother at a young age, (though not given up for adoption) and it had left me with a desire even as a child to adopt one day, in recognition of other children feeling "abandoned". Along the way, two girlfriends aborted. Through these experiences, I felt all the more for the vulnerable child. I had no doubt some day, children would play a role in my life. But in my 30s, a severe illness left me with infertility.

My views on adoption: there are many vulnerable children. We have no illusions, no hubris that we would be great parents, no insecurity children complete our lives/marriage and no sense these children need "saving" and we be "saviours". We reckon we will live the average human lifespan, and perhaps in that time help someone with whatever means we have. We will register and see what happens.

Some people think this is a rather "random" approach. But I think it is about as random as getting pregnant and not knowing how the child may turn out. I think it's part of our humanity, not destiny. We might adopt a child who grows up one day with deep anger issues, and all I can say is we will help that child manage that anger. We will help raise him/her especially with health and identity issues. I can have the best intentions but the relationship will pan out depending on the dynamics of any relationship. The only certainty is that deep-seated decision made as a child long ago to one day help other vulnerable children so they can make it through life.
